struct fla_htbl_entry#
#include <flexalloc_hash.h>

Hash table entry.

Public Members

uint64_t h2#

Secondary hash value.

The secondary hash value is used to distinguish collisions where two distinct input values yield the same hash value when using our primary hash function. Inserting a secondary hash into the table makes genuine collisions highly improbable.

uint32_t val#

The hash table entry value.

In case of

uint16_t psl#

Probe sequence length value.

The probe sequence length value effectively tracks how many places the element is away from its ideal hash table position.

We use this value with Robin Hood hashing during insertion to give priority to elements with a higher PSL - inserting our element if it has a higher PSL (already father from its ideal entry) than the currently examined element, continuing insertion by then trying to find a spot for the displaced element.

struct fla_pool#

Public Members

uint64_t h2#

h2 hash of entry.

Can be used to check that acquired pool entry’s name matches the name of the pool when the handle was made. This may prevent following stale handles to repurposed pool entries.

struct fla_pool_entry#

Public Members

uint32_t empty_slabs#

identifier for each slab depending on its “fullness”

uint32_t full_slabs#
uint32_t partial_slabs#
uint32_t obj_nlb#

Number of LBA’s used for each object in the cache.

Note that all objects in a cache have the same size. Also note that this is rounded up to fit alignment requirements.

uint32_t slab_nobj#

Number of Objects that fit in each slab.

uint64_t root_obj_hndl#

Root object that is optionally set.

Pools can have any valid flexalloc object set as a root object

uint32_t strp_nobjs#

Num of objects to stripe across.

Pools may optionally hand out striped objects

uint32_t strp_nbytes#

Number of bytes of each stripe chunk.

When striped, each fla object is subdivided into stripe subsection or chunks. Must be set if we set strp_nobjs

char name[FLA_NAME_SIZE_POOL]#

Human-readable cache identifier.

The cache name is primarily used for debugging statistics and when creating the read-only file system view.

file flexalloc_bits.c
#include “flexalloc_bits.h”

Functions

uint32_t ntz(uint32_t x)#

Count number of trailing zero bits.

Given a 4B/32b value, count the number of trailing zero bits before encountering the first 1-bit.

Examples:

  • ntz(0) == 32

  • ntz(~0) == 0

  • ntz(4) == 2

uint32_t count_set_bits(uint32_t val)#

Count number of set bits.

Given a 4B/32b value, count the number of set bits.

Examples:

  • count_set_bits(0) == 0

  • count_set_bits(~0) == 32

  • count_set_bits(7) == 3

struct fla_daemon_client *fla_get_client(struct flexalloc const *const fs)#
int fla_max_open_files()#

int fla_daemon_create(struct fla_daemon *d, char *socket_path, fla_daemon_msg_handler_t on_msg, int max_clients, int conn_queue_length)#

Create flexalloc daemon instance.

Parameters

  • d – the daemon

  • socket_path – where to place the UNIX socket

  • on_msg – the handler which should parse messages received from the client

  • max_clients – maximum number of concurrent clients to support

  • conn_queue_length – maximum length of queue to buffer pending connection requests.

int fla_daemon_destroy(struct fla_daemon *d)#

Destroy daemon.

Call as part of the daemon shut down to release the UNIX socket etc.

Parameters

d – the (maybe initialized) daemon context

Returns

On success 0, -1 if closing the server socket fails, -2 if removing the socket file fails.

int fla_sock_send_bytes(int sock_fd, char *buf, size_t n)#

Send n bytes of data from buffer buf over provided socket.

Parameters

  • sock_fd – the socket file descriptor

  • buf – the data buffer

  • n – the number of bytes to send.

Returns

0 on success, positive values are application-specific, negative values are negated errno codes.

int fla_sock_send_msg(int sock_fd, struct fla_msg const *const msg)#

Send message to recipient over socket identified by sock_fd.

Note: A message is a byte array organized as [<op code: uint32_t>, <op length: uint32_t>, <data>], and the ‘op code’ value corresponds to the exact byte length of the ‘data’ byte array.

Parameters

  • sock_fd – the socket file descriptor of the receiving party

  • msg – the buffer containing the message to send

Returns

on success 0, -1 otherwise.

int fla_sock_recv_msg(int sock_fd, struct fla_msg const *const msg)#

Receive message from socket identified by sock_fd.

Note: A message is a byte array organized as [<op code: uint32_t>, <op length: uint32_t>, <data>], and the ‘op code’ value corresponds to the exact byte length of the ‘data’ byte array.

Parameters

  • sock_fd – the socket file descriptor or the sender

  • msg – the message buffer to receive the message contents

Returns

on success 0, -1 otherwise.

void fla_daemon_client_disconnect(struct pollfd *client, int *active_clients)#
int fla_daemon_loop(struct fla_daemon *d, volatile sig_atomic_t *keep_running)#

Start the daemon server loop.

Starts the daemon server loop which handles incoming connections, reads incoming messages and dispatches them to the provided handler function for processing.

Parameters

  • d – the daemon handler

  • keep_running – pointer to a variable indicating whether to continue the server loop, ideally configure a SIG-INT handler to set keep-value to zero, causing the server to gracefully exit the processing loop.

Returns

0 on success, non-zero in case of an unrecoverable error.

int fla_daemon_create(struct fla_daemon *d, char *socket_path, fla_daemon_msg_handler_t on_msg, int max_clients, int conn_queue_length)

Create flexalloc daemon instance.

Parameters

  • d – the daemon

  • socket_path – where to place the UNIX socket

  • on_msg – the handler which should parse messages received from the client

  • max_clients – maximum number of concurrent clients to support

  • conn_queue_length – maximum length of queue to buffer pending connection requests.

int fla_daemon_destroy(struct fla_daemon *d)

Destroy daemon.

Call as part of the daemon shut down to release the UNIX socket etc.

Parameters

d – the (maybe initialized) daemon context

Returns

On success 0, -1 if closing the server socket fails, -2 if removing the socket file fails.

int fla_sock_send_bytes(int sock_fd, char *buf, size_t n)

Send n bytes of data from buffer buf over provided socket.

Parameters

  • sock_fd – the socket file descriptor

  • buf – the data buffer

  • n – the number of bytes to send.

Returns

0 on success, positive values are application-specific, negative values are negated errno codes.

int fla_sock_send_msg(int sock_fd, struct fla_msg const *const msg)

Send message to recipient over socket identified by sock_fd.

Note: A message is a byte array organized as [<op code: uint32_t>, <op length: uint32_t>, <data>], and the ‘op code’ value corresponds to the exact byte length of the ‘data’ byte array.

Parameters

  • sock_fd – the socket file descriptor of the receiving party

  • msg – the buffer containing the message to send

Returns

on success 0, -1 otherwise.

int fla_sock_recv_msg(int sock_fd, struct fla_msg const *const msg)

Receive message from socket identified by sock_fd.

Note: A message is a byte array organized as [<op code: uint32_t>, <op length: uint32_t>, <data>], and the ‘op code’ value corresponds to the exact byte length of the ‘data’ byte array.

Parameters

  • sock_fd – the socket file descriptor or the sender

  • msg – the message buffer to receive the message contents

Returns

on success 0, -1 otherwise.

int fla_daemon_loop(struct fla_daemon *d, volatile sig_atomic_t *keep_running)

Start the daemon server loop.

Starts the daemon server loop which handles incoming connections, reads incoming messages and dispatches them to the provided handler function for processing.

Parameters

  • d – the daemon handler

  • keep_running – pointer to a variable indicating whether to continue the server loop, ideally configure a SIG-INT handler to set keep-value to zero, causing the server to gracefully exit the processing loop.

Returns

0 on success, non-zero in case of an unrecoverable error.

Functions

size_t fla_flist_size(uint32_t len)#

Return size, in bytes, needed to support a freelist of len entries.

Parameters

len – the number of entries to support.

Returns

the size required for the freelist, in bytes.

uint32_t fla_flist_len(freelist_t flist)#

Return length of freelist.

Returns the length of the freelist, defined as the number of slots which can be reserved or taken.

Parameters

flist – freelist handle

Returns

length of the freelist

uint32_t fla_flist_num_reserved(freelist_t flist)#

Return number of reserved entries in freelist.

Return number of entries already reserved by the freelist. Number of free entries can be determined by subtracting this value from fla_flist_len().

Parameters

flist – freelist handle

Returns

number of entries already reserved.

void fla_flist_reset(freelist_t flist)#

Reset freelist, setting all len entries to free.

Resets the freelist by freeing every one of the len entries.

Parameters

flist – freelist handle

void fla_flist_init(freelist_t flist, uint32_t len)#

Initialize the freelist.

Use this routine routine in case you allocate a buffer by other means (use fla_flist_size() to determine the required size) and wish to initialize the freelist. Note: if you wish to re-use an existing freelist, calling fla_flist_reset() will suffice.

Parameters

  • flist – freelist handle

  • len – length of the freelist. This should be the same length as provided when using fla_flist_size() to calculate the required buffer size.

int fla_flist_new(uint32_t len, freelist_t *flist)#

Create a new freelist.

Allocates and initializes a new freelist. Note that you can accomplish the same by using fla_flist_size() to calculate the required buffer size for a list of len entries. Allocate the buffer by whatever means you wish and call fla_flist_init() to initialize the freelist before use.

Parameters

  • len – length of the freelist to create

  • flist – pointer to a freelist handle

Returns

On success, 0 is returned and flist points to an initialized freelist. Otherwise, non-zero is returned and flist is uninitialized.

void fla_flist_free(freelist_t flist)#

Free buffer backing the freelist.

NOTE: only use this if freelist is allocated using fla_flist_new().

Parameters

flist – freelist handle

freelist_t fla_flist_load(void *data)#

Treat memory at data as an initialized freelist.

Use data pointed at by data as a freelist. This expects the buffer to be of sufficient length and its contents to be a freelist. That is, at some point it was initialized with fla_freelist_init() and since then only operated on using the fla_flist_* functions.

NOTE: no additional allocations are made and that the memory is still owned by you, do not use fla_flist_free() on the freelist handle!

Parameters

data – a buffer with data laid out by the freelist routines.

Returns

a freelist handle

int fla_flist_entry_alloc(freelist_t flist, uint32_t elems)#
int fla_flist_entries_alloc(freelist_t flist, unsigned int num)#

Allocate an entry from the freelist (if possible).

Allocates an entry from the freelist, if possible, and returns its index. An allocation may fail only if the freelist is full, in which case -1 is returned.

Parameters

  • flist – freelist handle

  • unsigned – int num of entries to allocate

Returns

On success, a value between 0 and len (the freelist length) indicating which element of the freelist has been reserved. On error, -1, in which case no allocation was made.

int fla_flist_entry_free(freelist_t flist, uint32_t ndx)#

Free an entry from the freelist.

Frees the element identified by ndx in the freelist.

NOTE: the free is idempotent, it is possible to free an already freed element.

NOTE: attempting to free an entry at an index outside the bounds of the freelist range returns -1.

Parameters

  • flist – freelist handle

  • ndx – index within the freelist of the element to free

Returns

On success, 0 is returned. On error, -1 is returned.

int fla_flist_entries_free(freelist_t flist, uint32_t ndx, unsigned int num)#

uint64_t fla_mad_compression(uint64_t key, uint64_t a, uint64_t b, uint64_t n)#

(M)ultiply (a)dd (d)ivide compression algorithm.

The compression function is used to compress hash values (2^64 range of values) to some smaller range, [0;n[.

Note: it should hold that: a % n != 0

Parameters

  • key – hash some hash value

  • a – some non-negative integer

  • b – some non-negative integer

  • n – maximum permitted value (your hash table’s size)

Returns

some value X where 0 <= x < n

void fla_htbl_entries_init(struct fla_htbl_entry *tbl, uint32_t tbl_size)#
int htbl_init(struct fla_htbl *htbl, unsigned int tbl_size)#

Initialize hash table.

NOTE: automatically called by htbl_new

int htbl_new(unsigned int tbl_size, struct fla_htbl **htbl)#

Allocates (& initializes) a new hash table with tbl_size entries.

Parameters

  • tbl_size – desired size of the backing table NOTE: the table size should be 2-3 times the size of the expected number of elements. Hash tables perform perform very poorly as they fill up.

  • htbl – pointer to hash table, will contain a reference to the constructed hash table

Returns

On success 0 and *htbl pointing to an allocated and initialized hash table. On error, non-zero and *htbl being undefined.

void htbl_free(struct fla_htbl *htbl)#

Free hash table.

Parameters

htbl – hash table

Insert entry into hash table.

NOTE: htbl_insert will update the existing entry if present.

Returns

0 if entry inserted or updated, otherwise an error.

void fla_close_noflush(struct flexalloc *fs)#

Close flexalloc system without writing changes to disk.

Closes the flexalloc system without flushing changes to the metadata to the disk. This is typically intended for read-only parsing of the flexalloc system state and as an escape-hatch in case there is no time to wait for the write to succeed.

NOTE: you will, by definition, lose changes if the meta data has changed since the last flush to disk.

Parameters

fs – flexalloc system handle

Free slab freelist cache memory.

Frees all memory associated the slab freelist and any IO-buffers.

NOTE: does not flush IO-buffers, any changes to the slab freelists not yet committed to disk will be lost!

Parameters

cache – slab freelist cache.

int fla_slab_cache_elem_init(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id, uint32_t flist_len)#

Initialize cache entry.

Initialize cache entry for the slab from scratch with an empty freelist whose size is inferred from the size of the objects (obj_nlb) to be served from the slab.

NOTE: incurs no disk I/O, the element may be explicitly flushed to disk using fla_slab_cache_elem_flush() if desired.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of the slab whose freelist to initialize

  • flist_len – intended length of freelist

Returns

On success 0 with the cache entry initialized and marked dirty. Non-zero otherwise with the cache entry unchanged. NOTE: FLA_SLAB_CACHE_INVALID_STATE is returned if the element is already initialized. Elements must be explicitly dropped, using fla_slab_cache_elem_drop() before being (re-)initialized. The element should be dropped when the slab is released from a pool back to the system.

int fla_slab_cache_elem_load(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id, uint32_t flist_len)#

Load cache entry freelist from disk.

Load existing slab freelist from disk. Pool management code should call this when loading in a slab which already exists on disk.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of the slab whose contents to load

  • flist_len – number of entries in freelist

Returns

On success 0 and the cache entry is populated, non-zero otherwise. NOTE: FLA_SLAB_CACHE_INVALID_STATE is returned if the element is already initialized. Elements must be explicitly dropped, using fla_slab_cache_elem_drop() before being (re-)initialized. The element should be dropped when the slab is released from a pool back to the system.

int fla_slab_cache_elem_flush(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id)#

Flush cache entry to disk.

Flush the slab freelist to disk and mark the cache entry as clean. This can be used explicitly to ensure object (de-)allocations are durable.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of slab whose freelist should be persisted

Returns

On success 0 with the cache element marked as clean. On error, non-zero with the cache element state unchanged.

void fla_slab_cache_elem_drop(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id)#

Mark cache entry data as invalid.

Marks cache entry data as invalid, freeing the associated freelist IO buffer, if any. This should be called by the pool when releasing a given slab.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of the slab whose cache entry to invalidate/drop

file flexalloc_slabcache.h
#include “flexalloc.h”

flexalloc Slab Freelist Cache

Copyright (C) 2021 Jesper Devantier j.devantier@samsung.com

Slab freelist cache

Each slab must maintain its own object allocation freelist. The exact size needed for the freelist depends on the number of objects that can fit into the slab, which in turn is determined by the pool object size. For this reason, the per-slab object freelists cannot be determined ahead of time, nor laid out contiguously on disk without over-provisioning space. Hence each slab maintains its own freelist, subtracting from the total space available in the slab.

As with other metadata, these freelists may require frequent checks and changes as objects are allocated or freed. To limit disk I/O overhead, the freelists will be cached in memory and flushed to disk as appropriate.

Defines

FLA_SLAB_CACHE_INVALID_STATE#

Enums

enum fla_slab_flist_elem_state#

State of slab freelist cache element.

Values:

enumerator FLA_SLAB_CACHE_ELEM_STALE#

A stale entry is one which is either not initialized or whose entry has been explicitly invalidated as part of the slab being released from the pool.

enumerator FLA_SLAB_CACHE_ELEM_DIRTY#

An entry is dirty if it contains changes which have not been written back to the disk.

enumerator FLA_SLAB_CACHE_ELEM_CLEAN#

An entry is clean if its contents are the same as on disk.

Functions

size_t fla_slab_cache_flist_nlb(struct flexalloc const *fs, uint32_t flist_len)

Determine number of logical blocks needed for a freelist with flist_len entries.

Determine number of logical blocks needed for a freelist of the specified size. Do not attempt to determine this number otherwise.

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • flist_len – number of entries to have in freelist

Returns

number of logical blocks required to contain the freelist

int fla_slab_cache_init(struct flexalloc *fs, struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache)

Initialize new slab freelist cache instance.

Initializes the cache and its elements. Note that the cache is tied to a particular flexalloc system instance due to the particulars of allocating IO-buffers for holding the freelists.

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • cache – an uninitialized cache struct

Returns

On success 0 and cache being initialized. On error, non-zero and cache is in an undefined state.

void fla_slab_cache_free(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache)

Free slab freelist cache memory.

Frees all memory associated the slab freelist and any IO-buffers.

NOTE: does not flush IO-buffers, any changes to the slab freelists not yet committed to disk will be lost!

Parameters

cache – slab freelist cache.

int fla_slab_cache_elem_init(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id, uint32_t flist_len)

Initialize cache entry.

Initialize cache entry for the slab from scratch with an empty freelist whose size is inferred from the size of the objects (obj_nlb) to be served from the slab.

NOTE: incurs no disk I/O, the element may be explicitly flushed to disk using fla_slab_cache_elem_flush() if desired.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of the slab whose freelist to initialize

  • flist_len – intended length of freelist

Returns

On success 0 with the cache entry initialized and marked dirty. Non-zero otherwise with the cache entry unchanged. NOTE: FLA_SLAB_CACHE_INVALID_STATE is returned if the element is already initialized. Elements must be explicitly dropped, using fla_slab_cache_elem_drop() before being (re-)initialized. The element should be dropped when the slab is released from a pool back to the system.

int fla_slab_cache_elem_load(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id, uint32_t flist_len)

Load cache entry freelist from disk.

Load existing slab freelist from disk. Pool management code should call this when loading in a slab which already exists on disk.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of the slab whose contents to load

  • flist_len – number of entries in freelist

Returns

On success 0 and the cache entry is populated, non-zero otherwise. NOTE: FLA_SLAB_CACHE_INVALID_STATE is returned if the element is already initialized. Elements must be explicitly dropped, using fla_slab_cache_elem_drop() before being (re-)initialized. The element should be dropped when the slab is released from a pool back to the system.

int fla_slab_cache_elem_flush(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id)

Flush cache entry to disk.

Flush the slab freelist to disk and mark the cache entry as clean. This can be used explicitly to ensure object (de-)allocations are durable.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of slab whose freelist should be persisted

Returns

On success 0 with the cache element marked as clean. On error, non-zero with the cache element state unchanged.

void fla_slab_cache_elem_drop(struct fla_slab_flist_cache *cache, uint32_t slab_id)

Mark cache entry data as invalid.

Marks cache entry data as invalid, freeing the associated freelist IO buffer, if any. This should be called by the pool when releasing a given slab.

Parameters

  • cache – slab freelist cache

  • slab_id – id of the slab whose cache entry to invalidate/drop

size_t strnlen(char *s, size_t maxlen)#

determine length of a fixed-size string.

Returns the length of the string, defined as the number of leading characters before the terminating null byte. If the string has no null-terminating byte within the first maxlen bytes strnlen() returns maxlen.

Parameters

  • s – the string

  • maxlen – maximum length of string

Returns

On success, length of string. On error, maxlen, meaning the string is not null-terminated within the first maxlen bytes.

  • xnvme_dev – Xnvme device

Flush flexalloc system state to disk.

Flush meta data changes to disk.

Parameters

fs – flexalloc system handle

Returns

On success 0.

int fla_pool_create(struct flexalloc *fs, const char *name, int name_len, uint32_t obj_nlb, struct fla_pool **pool)#

Create pool.

Creates and allocates a new pool in memory using the given name as its identifier. New pool is not created if it already exists with the same object size. Objects from the pool will span obj_nlb logical blocks. Will Not flush changes.

NOTE: to acquire the handle for an existing pool, use fla_pool_open()

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • name – Name of pool

  • name_len – Length of name string

  • obj_nlb – Size of objects to allocate from pool, in number of logical blocks.

  • pool – Pool handle, is initialized if acquisition of pool went well.

Returns

On success, 0 and *handle is initialized. On error, non-zero and *handle is undefined.

int fla_pool_destroy(struct flexalloc *fs, struct fla_pool *pool)#

Destroy pool and its resources.

Releases the pool and any slabs, and thereby objects, which it manages from memroy. Will not flush changes.

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • pool – Pool handle

Returns

On success, 0, the pool has been released. On error, non-zero - the pool has not been removed.

int fla_pool_open(struct flexalloc *fs, const char *name, struct fla_pool **pool)#

Allocates a pool handle.

Open and allocate (malloc) pool handle of existing pool, if it exists. Note, the pool must have been created earlier using fla_pool_create()

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • name – name of pool to find

  • pool – pool handle to initialize.

Returns

On success, 0 and handle is initialized. On error, non-zero with handle is undefined.

void fla_pool_close(struct flexalloc *fs, struct fla_pool *pool)#

Closes the pool handle by freeing its memory.

It will not close any of the related slabs or objects

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • pool – Pool handle to free

int fla_object_seal(struct flexalloc *fs, struct fla_pool const *pool_handle, struct fla_object *obj)

Seal a flexalloc object.

Runs logic signifying that the object will not be actively used. Seal is different from close in contexts like ZNS where objects cannot just re-open. Might be a noop.

Parameters

  • fs – flexalloc system handle

  • pool_handle – flexalloc pool handle associated with obj

  • obj – flexalloc object handle to close

Returns

0 on success. non zero otherwise.
